newsitem.title: USA: Cold Midwest weather slowing U.S. corn growth.
newsitem.headline: Cold Midwest weather slowing U.S. corn growth.

text.p: An extended period of abnormally cold weather across the U.S. Midwest is slowing the growth rate of early-planted corn, agronomists said.
"I don't think there is any question that we need warm temperatures to move the crops along," said Ellsworth Christmas, agronomist with Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind.
In Indiana, the corn that has emerged has good stand establishment, but the plants are very light in color because of recent cloudy and cool conditions, Christmas said.

Developmental problems have also been noted in Iowa and Illinois -- the country's two largest corn-producing states as well as Ohio, according to weekly crop data from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Crop scouts in those states reported Monday that farmers were concerned about germination of early-planted corn, corn plants that had emerged were yellow, and warmer temperatures were needed to spur growth.

In Iowa, nighttime temperatures this week have dropped below freezing in the northern half of the state, but there is little corn emerged there, so the weather was not seen as a threat, said Mark Carlton, a crop specialist for Iowa State University in Monroe County in southern Iowa.
"I think in the northern part of the state, there will be little or no weather damage to the corn crop," Carlton said.
In eastern Corn Belt states, more and more talk of the need to re-plant corn acreage has been surfacing, cash dealers and extension agents said.
"There's a fellow that is a customer of ours that planted in April, and he's going to have to tear up and replant nearly 1,000 acres," one Ohio grain dealer said.
In a weekly report circulated by Ohio State University crop extension agents, a section was devoted to factors that should affect the decision to replant corn.
"Although it's probably premature to raise the issue of replanting corn, below average temperatures and slow crop emergence have prompted requests for this information," the report said.

However, most agronomists agree it is still too early in the planting season to determine whether or not the corn crop's slow start will have an impact on yields and said a change in the weather would help the crop quickly recover.
"If we would warm it up 10 degrees and have clear skies, I think in a matter of four or five days, things would change dramatically," Christmas said.
However, near-term forecasts don't show much relief for Midwest farmers.
The weather outlook for the Midwest included scattered showers on Wednesday and Thursday, with temperatures staying below normal during that period, meteorologists said.

On Friday and Saturday, temperatures are forecast to drop to below-normal and much below normal levels but turn warmer on Sunday, according to a forecast from Weather Services Corp. in Lexington, Mass.
However, some other meteorologists expect a warming trend to begin Friday and last into the weekend.
